physDesc.p: This letter is two pages long. On the first page, the words “Poetry Monroe” are written in pencil at the top left

encodingDesc.p: This letter contains references to the following:

div.p: I am enclosing “Lead Soldiers.” Of course you want it. You have got to want it. I consider it the best thing I have done. You must want it. You shall want it. Now be good and want it! I don’t agree with you a bit about its not going with the others. I think it would make the head of a group very well. I would not put it at the end.

As you know, you have had some of my things since last May, and I should like them to appear during the summer. You have printed me a lot, and I am very grateful; but I do want to head the number again soon.

I am glad you like the looks of the Anthology and I hope you will like the inside as well. I guess you did not read the preface carefully, or you would have seen why we mentioned the other Anthology: merely to explain our schism and how much we held with it and how much we didn’t.

¶ Please look at my poem that is coming out
in the Imagist number of “The Egoist.” I think you will like it.
div.closer: Always with a great deal of love,

postscript.p: P.S. I enclose cheque to pay for the extra copies of “Poetry.”

Do you want to ask McClurg if they won’t take 25 or 30 copies of the Imagist number of “The Egoist” for sale on commission? I have Gomme’s bookshop in New York to take 50 copies, and the Old Corner Bookstore here the same. They, of course, are not paying anything for them, and they will gain by their own commission if they sell any. If you could make the same arrangement with McClurg, I think it would be fine. I can send them copies as soon as they send them to me. As you were mentioned in that, Fletcher having designated you “the discoverer of Imagism” it ought to be a good thing for you as well as for us. Miss Weaver will let us have them for $1.35.
(Indecipherable) they tell me at the Old Corner Bookstore here that they can retail them at 25¢.
